body_text.text: C:onsitierabl{' information on sex and ag<, strudUft'S of ]Joplllati()l1~ H'-p<;tabIL,lwd ill dl']Jojlulat(,d arcas through immigration, and of emigrants from populations undergoing dispersal is available for cricetids (Stickel, 1946; Smith, 1968; Smyth, 1968; Van Vleck, 1968; Myers and Krebs, 1971; Joule and Cameron, 1975; Lidicker, 1975; Fairbairn, 1978; Gaines and McClenaghan, 1980; Keith and Tamarin, 1981) , sciurids (Davis et al., 1964; Slade and Balph, 1974; Michener and Michener, 1977; Dobson, 1979 Dobson, , 1981 , and leporids (Windberg and Keith, I976a, 1976b) , However, relatively few removal or perturbation e~pt'rirrl('Tlts haVE' been conducted with heteromyids. French et al. (1968) recorded dispersal movements in four species of heteromyids but reported sex and age characteristics only for Perognathus formosus. Schroder and Rosenzweig (1975) found populations of two species of Dipodomys contained large numbers of transients that quickly replaced residents removed. They did not report ages of residents, those removed, or immigrants, but they suggested that both sexes "were equally prone to move about" (p. 22), The apparent paucity of information on sex and age characteristics of resident and immigrant heteromyids prompted us to attempt to ascertain the dispersal strategy for a population of Great Basin pocket mice (Perognathus parvus).

The study was conducted on a L8-ha plot established near the center of a 4.5-ha nearly pure stand of gray rabbitbrush (Chrysothamnus nauseosus) on the 20,OOO-ha u.s. Navy Bombing Range near Boardman, Morrow elk Oregon (45"51'\', 119°42'\V). Other vegetation on the study plot consisted of 'icattered cheatgrass (Bromus tectorum), buckwheat (Eriogonum sp.), Sandberg bluegrass (Foa secunda), and matchweed (Gutierrezia sarothrae) On 30 June 1980, 100 Sherman live traps were set in a 10-by lO-station grid with IS m between stations. Traps, baited with rolled oats and set on 15 consecutive evenings, were examined and dosed each morning. Sex, weight to the nearest 1.0 g, and the toe-dip mark used to distinguish each individual were recorded; P. parous that weighed 14 g or less were considered juveniles, Animals caught during the first 7 days were released at their respective points of capture; by 7 days, the proportion of unmarked individuals in the daily catch approached an asymptote suggesting that most residents were marked ( Fig. 1 )_ In an attempt to speed removal of residents, an additional trap was set at each station on days 8, 9, and 10. On day 8, all mice captured, both marked and unmarked, were considered residents and were removed from the study area; on days 9 and 10, only mice marked during the first 7 days were removed, and newly captured mice were marked and released as before. During days 11-15, newly-captured animals were marked and released as before the removal period.

Chi-square and chi-square in R by 2 contingency tables were used to test for differences between numbers observed and expected by sex, age, trapping period, and spatial distribution. When contingency tables indicated independence of sex and age within samples, samples were grouped by sex or age to test for differences between trapping periods. In all statistical analyses, P < 0.05 was accepted as the level of significance In 1,800 trap nights, 239 pocket mice, 2 Ord's kangaroo rats (Dipodomys ordii), 2 northern grasshopper mice (Onychomys leucogaster), and I deer mouse (Peromyscus maniculatus) were captured. The 239 P. pamus were captured a total of 785 times, Because of their overwhelming dominance, only pocket mice were considered in analysis of removal and immigration.

During the first 7 days, 137 pocket mice were captured; 8 died in traps presumably leaving 129 marked individuals on the study area ( Table l) . Sex and age within the sample of 137 were independent (X 2 = 0.246, d.£. = 1), but adults occurred in significantly greater numbers than juveniles (X 2 = 7,949, dJ. = 1).

During the 3-day removal period, 90 pocket mice marked during the first 7 days and 14 unmarked mice were removed (Table 1 ). Sex and age within the sample of 104 also were independent (XL = 0.349, doL = 1), and adults again occurred in significantly greater numbers than juveniles (x 2 = 3.846, d.£. = 1). Thus, the sample removed closely reflected (X2 = 1.054, d.£. = 3) the population as revealed by livetrapping before removal; it was biased toward the adult cohort Of the 104 mice removed, only 7 were caught in the 100 traps added during the 3-day removal period; the remaining 97 were caught in traps in place during the initial 7-day period. Five of the seven were marked and two were unmarked; all sex and age dasses were represented, Six of the seven were caught on the first day the added traps were in place (day 8), one on the second day, and none on the third day, whereas traps in place during the initial 7-day period caught 75, 40, and 43 P. parous during the 3 days, respectively_ We are unable to account for the obvious avoidance of the newly placed traps. A neophobic , 1971 ) seem~ unlikely as the traps were identical with those in place during the first 7-day period and, among the few P. parvus caught in the added traps, all sex and age classes were

represented. The newly placed traps were well used and unwashed, although they were not used earlier where P. parous was abundant. Also, the added traps did not become progressively attractive from earlier captures of P. pamus as expected or as occurred among traps in place during the initial 7-day period (Fig. 1) .

During the postremoval period (beginning on day 9 as all newly captured pocket mice on and after that date were marked and released), 88 unmarked individuals were captured, marked, and released (Table 1) Sex and age within the sample were independent (X' = 1.252, d.f. = 1), but juveniles occurred in significantly greater numbers than adults (X2 = 4.545, d.f. = 1). However, age ratios did not remain constant in the postremoval period; during the first 3 days, 28 adults and 32 juveniles were captured, whereas during the last 4 days, 6 adults and 22 juveniles were caught Thus, juveniles comprised a significantly larger proportion of the catch (X~ = 5.130, dJ. = 1) during the last part of the postremoval period than during the early part Also, pocket mice caught on the area after removal trapping (Table 1) consisted of significantly fewer adults than occurred in the population before removal (X' = 11.462, d.L = 1).

Only six pocket mice caught during the first 7-day period were recaptured during the postremoval period (days 11-15). One marked pocket mOU5e was found dead on the study area, so, of the 137 pocket mice that constituted the initial marked population, only 32 remained unaccounted for at the end of the study; 17 of the:32 "'ere captured only one tinH'. \\"ithilt tIl(' ';lmple of :32 not caught ;lfter tIlt' initi;ll marking period. sex and age were not independent (x' = 5.2:36, d.L = 1); adult males comprised 44% of the sample (Table I) Of the pocket mice removed, approximately 30% were replaced by unmarked individuals the following night, more than half were replaced within 3 nights, and about 85% were replaced within a week (Table  2) . Thus, in a week, the number of unmarked individuals caught on the study plot equalled 68% of the number marked and presumed alive at the end of the preremoval phase.

To ascertain if pocket mice caught during days 9-15 moved onto the study plot from surrounding portions of the community, we hypothesized that immigrants would be intercepted by the peripheral row of traps as reported for Microtus pennsyltJGnicus (Van Vleck, 1968) . Thus, on the basis of effort, first captures of immigrants should be more frequent than expected in the 36 traps in the peripheral row of stations and less frcquent than expected in the 64 traps in the 8-by 8-station core of the grid. !\"umbers captured on the two portiuns of the grid during this period (Fig. 1) were almost exactly as expected (x 2 = 0.023, dJ. = 1). However, first captures during the first 7-day mark-and-release period (Fig. 1 ) occurred more frequently than expected in traps within the core of the grid (Xl = 6.497, d.£. = 1) and all recaptures throughout the study occurred much more frequently than expected within the core of the grid (Fig. 1 ) (X 2 = 49.106, d.f. = 1).

Potentially, unmarked animals in samples collected after removal of a portion of a population could be immigrants that invaded from nearby areas (Stickel, 1946) or they could be behaviorally subordinate individuals that were prevented from entering traps until dominant individuals were removed (Andrzejewski et aL, 1959) . The latter situation would be more common on study plots such as ours where a large proportion of traps were occupied each night because of the relatively dense population. If a large proportion of the population were prevented from entering traps either because traps were occupied already or because of scent marks left at traps by behaviorally dominant individuals (Summerlin and Wolfe, 1973) , the addition of 100 traps should have revealed this otherwise inconspicious portion of the population even if there were initial avoidance of the newly placed traps. Yet, few mice were caught in traps added during the removal phase even though increasing numbers of unmarked mice were trapped immediately after commencing removal (Table 2 ). In addition, the proportion of unmarked mice caught on days 9, 10, and 11 composed of adult, and presumably dominant, individuals (Summerlin and Wolfe, 1973) was greater than caught later in the postremoval period; thus, we suggest that the unmarked mice that appeared in the catch immediately after removal trapping, indeed, were immigrants.

Although we cannot offer a plausable explanation for the apparent avoidance of traps in the peripheral row of stations by first captures during the preremoval phase or by all recaptures (Fig. n the failure of unmarked mice to avoid traps in the peripheral row during the postremoval phase also supports our contention that they were immigrants intercepted during dispersal onto the depopulated area If part of the P. parous population remained unsettled and highly mobile as suggested for Dipodomys (Schroder and Rosenzweig, 1975) , we expected that those caught the fewe~t times (presumahly they would be present on the grid only part of the time) to exhibit the greatest mobility. During the 7-day preremoval period, 49 (82%) of 60 pocket mice caught three or more times and 22 (79%) of 28 caught twice did not move more than one between-station interval. The nearly identical proportions that did not move more than one between-station interval (X" = 0.121, d.L = 1) suggests that P. parvus populations may not contain a similar transient component. During days 9-15, 38 (72%) of 53 previously unmarked mice caught three or more times did not move more than one between-station interval, suggesting that immigrants established residence quickly.

The dispersal strategy exhibited by P. parvus of parity between sexes and a significantly greater proportion of juveniles seemed superficially similar to that of some cricetids (Stickel, 1946; Smith, 1968; Smyth, 1968; Fairbairn, 1978) , but cnnsiderably different from that of several others (Gaines and McClenaghan, 1980) . In Ollr study, the initial influx after removal was comprised of nearly equal numbers of adults and juveniles, and later immigrants were so predominantly juvenile that the entire postremoval sample was biased toward juveniles. Whether the dispersal strategy of our population of P. parvus was truly uniquE' or derived its apparent uniqueness from other investigators failing to analyze for temporal shifts in age ratios among immigrants is uncertain.

We thank B. E. Coblentz, M. L. Johnson, and an anonymous reviewer for comments on the manuscript G. Green assisted in establishing the study area and with field work. An earlier draft was submitted by the ~enior author as an undergraduate thesis for the Honors Program at Oregon State University. This is Technical Paper No 5986, Oregon Agricultural Experiment Station.
